title: Julian Fellowes webchat â your questions answered on The Wind in the Willows, Downton Abbey, winning an Oscar â and Nando's | Stage | The Guardian
summary: have i ever been to nando 's ? yes !
after winning an oscar , i became , briefly , the patron of the last-chance saloon .
the wind in the willows was my chance to look at friendship .
robert altman called gosford park a 'who cares whodunnit ? '
it 's pretty likely the downton movie will happen .
post your questions for julian fellowes .

text: guardian contributor julianfellowes 13 june 2017 2:14pm thank you for the questions - i 'm flattered that you 're interested .
it 's a nice feeling - not just that people are enjoying the show but also that they want to know more about the people who made it .
donrodrigo asks : do you put milk first in your tea or last ?
and do you take sugar ?
guardian contributor julianfellowes 13 june 2017 2:11pm last .
and i never take sugar in tea .

documents.title: have i ever been to nando 's ? yes !
text: peely1 asks : have you ever been to nando 's ?
guardian contributor julianfellowes 13 june 2017 2:10pm yes !
there 's an excellent one in dorchester , right next to the cinema .
donrodrigo asks : how tall are you ?
guardian contributor julianfellowes 13 june 2017 2:09pm 5ft 10in
pagey asks : are you planning to write anything in a contemporary setting , outside of your direct experience ?
i believe there is too much reverence for costume drama on the big terrestrial channels , which is an easy sell to the us market and its fetish for the lives of the british upper classes .
toby lee ( zack ) , david flynn ( dewey finn ) and selma hansen ( katie ) in school of rock , book by julian fellowes .
kenton for the guardian guardian contributor julianfellowes 13 june 2017 2:08pm i 've become a go-to guy for period drama .
in this business , you normally get your lucky break because you become known as being reliable for a certain type of part or story .
it does n't mean it 's the only thing you can do .
my own favourite , among my work , is a film starring tom wilkinson and emily watson called separate lies .
it 's not about class at all , or any of the themes i 'm famous for .
i really enjoyed school of rock which shook up the pattern a bit .
show business is the business of supply - if there 's an audience for a product you know how to provide , then it 's foolish to stay away .
i 'm about to make a period drama in new york , the chaperone , set in the 20s .
i 'm lucky to be known for a certain type of work .
actors should n't be afraid of typecasting - eventually you will get the opportunity to vary your output .
at the beginning , just give thanks to the fact that you 're working .
bishop basher asks : do you have a butler ?
guardian contributor julianfellowes 13 june 2017 2:00pm no !
harphilby asks : why did n't you extend downton abbey into the 1930s and the rise of hitler ?
within that estate you could have chamberlain/baldwin/appeasers , the churchillians , communists , mosley 's fascists .
great fun .
lady mary should be appeaser who realises her grave error .
guardian contributor julianfellowes 13 june 2017 2:00pm for me , in one way , i felt i 'd already done that in gosford .
i did think it would be fun to do it in the 70s .
in the whole series we went from 1912 to 1925 and you can believably keep the same actors in that range - maybe with a bit more grey at the temples .
if there 's a bigger jump in time there 's less believability in it .

25aubrey asks : one thing i could n't come to terms with in monarch of the glen was how intensely miserable alexander morton 's character golly was thank goodness for the sublime geographical back drop to ease the pain .
is he the most disconsolate character you 've appeared alongside ?
he gave me the impression if he won the european lottery , he 'd still go and repair a crumbling estate wall , than get into the local for a few celebratory drams .
monarch of the glen ¦ fellowes is fourth from the right , as kilwillie , and alexander morton , playing golly is far right .
buitendijk/bbc guardian contributor julianfellowes 13 june 2017 1:57pm i 'm interested that you see golly as so incredibly miserable .
i was never aware of that .
lots of people think i wrote monarch of the glen but i did n't - it had a team of writers .
golly was quite down to earth , not given to seeing the sunny side of things .
i wanted very much to get off with molly but the bbc made her get off with golly .
i was going to write them a balcony scene .
harriet crampton asks : kia ora from new zealand .
i really want to know why you had lord and lady grantham sleeping in the same room .
it felt factually wrong and a missed opportunity in terms of story , but i 'm sure you had a good reason for this choice and i 'd love to know what it was .

guardian contributor julianfellowes 13 june 2017 1:55pm it 's true that upper-class couples used to have two bedrooms but this developed at the turn of the century into there being a bedroom and also a dressing room with a bed in it .
they always wanted the option of sleeping apart .
that was simply a custom among their type .
the bedroom was always called 'the woman 's bedroom ' never 'their bedroom ' .
that was where the marital bed was .
he would have a made-up bed in a dressing room .
so if , at the last minute , one of them decides they have a cold or they need to get up early in the morning , nothing has to be done .
that continues to the present day .
but the idea that they really slept apart was a myth .
they certainly dressed apart - never in front of each other .
bakelite asks : what 's your advice for writers who want to break through in their 50s ?
give up ?
guardian contributor julianfellowes 13 june 2017 1:52pm it sounds feeble but you have to write .
not talk about writing and think about writing .
and you have to write even when you do n't feel like it .
and do n't show anyone anything if you still feel like you need to qualify it .

you should never hear yourself saying , `` i know chapter 3 does n't really work yet `` everyone turned bob altman 's idea - tom stoppard , christopher hampton - and then he got to the end of the line .
i 'd written one script for one of his producers and that 's how i got the break .
it was so random .
i was used to banging my head against a brick wall and when it turned into a door no one was more surprised than me .
tippisheadrun asks : did you ever consider pairing the widowed lady mary with her brother-in-law tom in downton abbey ?
i spent three seasons confidently predicting that they would end up together .
also , thanks for spratt-denker .
guardian contributor julianfellowes 13 june 2017 1:49pm the short answer is no .
as the series went on , i toyed with the idea but i did n't feel it was right .
fans did write in and suggest it .
but i thought mary was too much of a snob .
sybil could marry tom on equal terms , the difference in their background did n't interest either of them .
the other thing was that i felt what those three girls had never had was a brother .
what tom gave mary - and to a degree edith - was that kind of relationship .
the english upper classes must never show that things are going badly within their families .
they always keep a good front on - they think they 're letting the show down if they do n't .
it 's a bit like the americans .
when an american confides in you that something is going badly , you should consider yourself a real friend .
also , i wanted a full series of mary basically fooling around !
michelle dockery as lady mary in downton abbey briggs/ap
stellainparis asks : i ca n't wait for your next show , the gilded age .
do you have any news to share about it ?
also , i was wondering if your work is inspired by edith wharton ?
( as a french writer , i 'm interested in her work and life . )
guardian contributor julianfellowes 13 june 2017 1:44pm i discovered edith wharton quite late in life .
i was in my 40s when i first read her .
i became a big fan , i went to see her house out at lenox , called the mount .
i 've been given a lifetime award by the edith wharton society .
what she explores is a period of the crossing of two waters in new york - you had the old landed gentry - the younger sons mainly - and from them came george washington , thomas jefferson .
they were the dominant social class .
they lived in largish , simple houses in washington square .
and into that culture came this torrent of money after the civil war .
these people decided to come and spend their fortunes in new york and they started to build palaces up fifth avenue .
park avenue became a great boulevard of new york .
if you go up to the 80s , 90s addresses you can still see these palaces .
and there was this great battle of these two social groups .
and there was this woman , caroline astor , who came from old , original 17th-century settlers and she felt this gave her the right to be the determiner of who was in and who was out .
she recognised that new york society had to expand - that there could n't be two rival societies side by side .
she was very powerful .
that 's the background of what the gilded age series will look at

documents.title: after winning an oscar , i became , briefly , the patron of the last-chance saloon
text: haveoneonme3 asks : somebody once said , on winning an oscar : you win an oscar , you enjoy the night , and then you wake up the next morning and nothing changes .
what are your feelings now on your oscar win ?
guardian contributor julianfellowes 13 june 2017 1:36pm winning an oscar is different for different people .
when a great star , already at the top of their profession , wins one then it 's a fitting tribute to their achievements and their contribution to the industry .
but it does n't change their career .
that was n't at all the case with me .
i was a complete unknown - a mildly familiar actor in britain .
people would see my face and think we 'd met at a house party in norfolk .
i became , briefly , the patron of the last chance saloon .
in hollywood , they think if you 've got the right stuff it would have manifested itself by the time you 're in your 30s .
i was 51 or 52 - and a complete unknown .
in the writers ' guild they have an oscar party and i heard they gave out a great cheer when i won - they were saying , do n't dismiss writers of that age .
so it changed everything .
i woke up after a riotous night and there was the oscar on my bedside table .
and i thought , everything 's different .
i did one more season on monarch and was almost immediately offered mary poppins to write for cameron mackintosh - then i had a bestseller with snobs .
then i was offered a film to direct .
the oscar made me a player .
i always feel it took an american outside the system to do that for me .
that was bob altman .
he was my lucky break .
i would n't have made it through in the british industry in the same way .
guardian contributor julianfellowes 13 june 2017 1:36pm the truth is you need a lucky break .
people talk about making your own luck .
but the fact is you need a bit of luck .
there are people out there far more talented than i am but they never had that bit of luck .

documents.title: the wind in the willows was my chance to look at friendship
text: jordandsmith21 asks : in a lot of your works the themes of class conflict , political upheaval , social change and the myths of the edwardian golden age are quite prevalent .
i was wondering whether these themes had any bearing on the writing of your new musical adaptation of the wind in the willows .

guardian contributor julianfellowes 13 june 2017 1:29pm it 's quite true that social change is of great interest to me - i 've written a lot about periods - the 1910s , the 1920s - when a lot was changing for a lot of people .
in every era , the manners and customs of the previous age linger on but at the same time a new world is manifesting itself .
yet we probably all celebrate christmas much as we did when we were children and get married in ways that we would have done in the 50s .
i 've looked at that in gosford and downton .
for me , a greater theme of my own work - if i can talk about it in such a pompous manner - is self-knowledge .
that 's a theme in wind in the willows more than social change .
animals simply do n't change - you ca n't impose that on the animal kingdom .
william the conqueror 's enjoyment of a squirrel would be much the same as my own .
i suppose some animals see others as instinctive enemies , that 's part of their social fabric , so we engage with that a bit .

but really for me , beneath the children 's story , it 's a sophisticated examination of different types of friends - the impossible ones that drive you mad , the ones who frighten you , the ones you love because they 're so affectionate .
we could probably all put names to the characters in the stories .
the original impossible friend is , of course , toad .
for most of us our friendships are a key part of our emotional lives but fiction does n't do much with friendship - usually it 's about negative aspects , not people just being friends .
butch cassidy and the sundance kid really looks at friendship .
this was my chance to look at friendship - it was already a favourite book of mine .
i loved it as a child .
i was jolly pleased to be asked to do it .
stiles and drewe and i are an old team as i did mary poppins and half a sixpence with them .

documents.title: robert altman called gosford park a 'who cares whodunnit ? '
text: usefulmirage 3d asks : i really liked gosford park .
why do n't you write more whodunnits ?
guardian contributor julianfellowes 13 june 2017 1:21pm well , it was n't really a whodunnit - robert altman himself called it a 'who cares whodunnit ? '
he would turn genres on their head - like a western that is n't really a western ( mccabe and mrs miller ) or a thriller that is n't a thriller ( the gingerbread man ) .
i was more interested in the way of life - this undertow of an end of a way of life .
one of the scenes they cut , which saddened me , was of the servants talking about their ambitions .
the older servants are shocked that the younger ones do n't want to stay in service .
there was a whodunnit element but i was n't terribly good at it .
i would n't know where to start a thriller - though i enjoy watching them - jagged edge , fatal attraction .
that 's my favourite movie excursion : a full-blooded hollywood thriller .
clive owen and kelly macdonald in gosford park .
/allstar
robertdale 4d asks : when is never mind the full stops coming back ?
guardian contributor julianfellowes 13 june 2017 1:17pm my guess would be never but i 'd welcome it if it did .
it was very good fun .
the show was all about words and punctuation and regional accents - some of them i really could n't understand .
you tend to think that the modern world irons out accents and that they get softer , but the show proved they were n't .
janet street porter had a great ear for the accents .
never mind the full stops ¦ julian fellowes presenting the programme .
/todd antony/bbc

documents.title: it 's pretty likely the downton movie will happen
text: thebigappel asks : please update fans on the status of the downton abbey film and gilded age series .
rumours for and against their realisation have come and gone .
still , no product .
i fear that after a while , only i will be interested in them .
momentum is so fickle .
guardian contributor julianfellowes 13 june 2017 1:14pm i keep being asked about the downton film .
i 've done some work on the script because i do n't want to find there 's a green light and no script ready .
but we 're still waiting for that green light from the studio .
then the biggest difficulty will be rounding up all the cast as , compared with most series , it has such a large cast .
and it needs them to feel downtonesque .
i know the cast are behind it and there 's a big audience out there .
on most movies , unless it 's spider-man 6 , you 're taking a punt .
but it 's pretty likely the downton movie will happen .
as for the gilded age having spent six years on downton , i wanted a bit of time in between that and the next thing .
i 've been pretty busy with school of rock , half a sixpence and wind in the willows .
and i 've had some fun on television .
i 'm trying to tidy my desk .
as an actor , it 's hard to say no to anything - and that continues as a writer .
so i want to tidy my desk of commitments and move on with the gilded age - a new world and a new bunch of characters .
that 's why i 've been so slow off the mark with it .
julian fellowes is here for a guardian webchat .
wiegand for the guardian guardian contributor julianfellowes 13 june 2017 1:09pm hello !
i 'm flattered to be invited here and interested to see these questions from guardian readers .
here we go

documents.title: post your questions for julian fellowes
text: julian fellowes will always be best known for creating one of the world 's most popular tv series .

but before he dreamed up the glorious period drama downton abbey , fellowes had already built a jolly good career as an actor with a cv including roles as winston churchill ( twice ) and noã « l coward , and appearances in tomorrow never dies , monarch of the glen and our friends in the north .

he 's scrutinised england 's obsession with class in his bestselling novels such as snobs and movie scripts for vanity fair , the young victoria and the oscar-winning country-house whodunnit gosford park .
( he keeps his statuette in the billiard room . )
fellowes even had a stint as the quizmaster of a grammatical gameshow on bbc4 .
then there 's the 2010 peerage that gave him a seat on the conservative benches .
he has written a run of theatre hits , too , enjoying west end and broadway success with mary poppins and school of rock .

before his new show , the wind in the willows , blows into the london palladium , julian will be answering your questions about his career in a live webchat at 1pm bst on tuesday 13 june post them in the comments below .

bulletin.text: The Downton Abbey creator answered your questions on his new TV show The Gilded Age, Gosford Park and whether he has a butler.
